content: The sunspot regions shown in the images are a study in contrast. Bright hot plasma flows upward on the sun’s surface, while darker, cooler plasma flows down. In the chromosphere, the atmospheric layer above the surface, threadlike structures reveal the presence of magnetic fields.

article.title: New unprecedented images reveal what’s happening on the sun as it approaches ‘solar maximum’
article.author: Ashley Strickland

content: Fine, detailed structures, including glowing dots that exist where the magnetic field is the strongest, can be seen in the dark sunspots. Bright strands derived from the magnetic field called penumbral filaments, which transport heat, surround the sunspot.

article.title: New unprecedented images reveal what’s happening on the sun as it approaches ‘solar maximum’
article.author: Ashley Strickland

content: Another image shows a sunspot that has lost the majority of its brighter, surrounding region, or penumbra, which seems to be decaying. Researchers believe the remaining fragments could be the end point in the evolution of a sunspot, before it disappears.

article.title: New unprecedented images reveal what’s happening on the sun as it approaches ‘solar maximum’
article.author: Ashley Strickland

content: The Inouye Solar Telescope also glimpsed “light bridges,” bright solar features that span the darkest region of a sunspot. These complex structures can differ in appearance, but scientists think light bridges could signal that a sunspot is about to decay. Future observations could provide more data about the formation of light bridges and their significance.

article.title: New unprecedented images reveal what’s happening on the sun as it approaches ‘solar maximum’
article.author: Ashley Strickland

content: The images taken over the past year were among some of the first observations using the world’s largest and most powerful ground-based solar telescope during its commissioning phase, according to the National Science Foundation. Currently, the telescope is being brought up to its full operational capabilities, according to the agency.

article.title: New unprecedented images reveal what’s happening on the sun as it approaches ‘solar maximum’
article.author: Ashley Strickland

content: Scientists hope the telescope’s capabilities will allow them to answer key questions about the sun, including the origin of solar storms, as well as unlock the complexities of its magnetic field.

article.title: New unprecedented images reveal what’s happening on the sun as it approaches ‘solar maximum’
article.author: Ashley Strickland

content: The telescope was designed to make ongoing measurements of the magnetic fields in the sun’s corona and provide images of the solar atmosphere like never before. Compared with other observatories’ imaging capabilities, Inouye can capture solar features three times smaller.

article.title: New unprecedented images reveal what’s happening on the sun as it approaches ‘solar maximum’
article.author: Ashley Strickland

content: Solar data from the Inouye Solar Telescope, as well as two space-based missions called Solar Orbiter and the Parker Solar Probe, can help unravel some of the sun’s enduring mysteries — all while providing stunning views of our star in a new light.

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: Ukrainian armed forces on Friday identified a large Russian landing ship that they said they destroyed at the port of Berdiansk in southern Ukraine the day before.

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: The port, which had recently been occupied by Russian forces with several Russian warships in dock, was rocked by a series of heavy explosions soon after dawn on Thursday.

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: Social media videos showed fires raging at the dockside, with a series of secondary explosions reverberating across the city.

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: The Ukrainian armed forces on Friday named the ship as the “Saratov.” In earlier reporting, the ship was named as the “Orsk.”

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: In a statement, the armed forces said: “In the Azov operational zone, according to updated information, a large landing ship “Saratov” was destroyed during the attack on the occupied Berdiansk port. Large landing ships “Caesar Kunikov” and “Novocherkassk” were [also] damaged. Other losses of the enemy are being clarified.”

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: Several Russian ships had been unloading military equipment at Berdiansk in recent days, according to reports from the port by Russian media outlets.

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: The United States said that Ukraine likely did conduct a successful attack against Russian ships in Berdiansk, according to a defense official, though it is unclear what type of weapon or weapons were used in the attack. It echoes a similar statement from the British Ministry of Defence, which said that Ukrainian forces have attacked “high value targets” in Russian-occupied areas of Ukraine, including a landing ship and ammunition depots at Berdiansk.

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: Analysis of videos uploaded on Thursday showed that one Russian naval vessel left the port soon after the explosions.

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: The Russian Ministry of Defense has made no official comment about the explosion.

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: Berdiansk sits on the Azov Sea and is roughly 45 miles (70 kilometers) southwest of Mariupol. The city has a small naval base and a population of about 100,000.

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: Russian military troops first occupied Berdiansk government buildings on February 27, three days after Russia’s invasion began.

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: Mariupol still eludes Russian control despite being surrounded and mercilessly pummeled, block by block, by Russian firepower.

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: Its defenders rejected an ultimatum to surrender by Monday morning, thwarting a Russian effort to finalize a land bridge linking Crimea with the separatist republics of the eastern Donbas region.

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: Russia has fired on Mariupol from the Sea of Azov, according to a senior US defense official, using a group of approximately seven ships to launch attacks on the critical coastal city.

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: Further west, Ukrainians have been fighting to take back the city of Kherson, as well as pushing Russian forces from the northeast of Mykolaiv, forcing them to reposition south of the city, a senior US defense official said Tuesday.

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: The official cautioned that the US cannot say whether these moves are part of a “larger operational plan” by the Ukrainians, but called the Ukrainian defense “nimble” and “agile.”

article.title: Ukrainians claim to have destroyed large Russian warship in Berdiansk
article.author: Andrew Carey|Tim Lister|Celine Alkhaldi|Olga Voitovych|Gianluca Mezzofiore

content: This story has been updated with new information from Ukrainian officials.

article.title: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts
article.author: Melissa Gray|Sania Farooqui

content: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts

article.title: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts
article.author: Melissa Gray|Sania Farooqui

content: Three cheetah cubs have died in India this week, dealing yet another setback to a historic effort by the government to reintroduce the species to the country after 70 years of extinction.

article.title: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts
article.author: Melissa Gray|Sania Farooqui

content: The cubs were part of a litter of four born in late March to a cheetah named Siyaya, who was one of eight rehabilitated cheetahs brought from Namibia to India’s Kuno National Park, in the central state of Madhya Pradesh, in September last year.

article.title: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts
article.author: Melissa Gray|Sania Farooqui

content: The first cub died Tuesday morning, said JS Chauhan, chief conservator of the Forest Department of the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh in an interview with local media. Over the next two days, two other cubs succumbed to “heat, dehydration and weakness,” forest department officials said.

article.title: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts
article.author: Melissa Gray|Sania Farooqui

content: The fourth cub was also rescued and taken to a local hospital for monitoring, Chauhan said.

article.title: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts
article.author: Melissa Gray|Sania Farooqui

content: “Its condition was also not very good, but after treatment, the cub is looking much better, though the cub is underweight and a bit weak. Both the mother and her remaining cub continue to remain under observation”, he added.

article.title: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts
article.author: Melissa Gray|Sania Farooqui

content: The government did not give the cause of death, but the day they died was one of the hottest of the season, with temperatures hitting up to 46-47 degrees Celsius (114-116 degrees Fahrenheit).

article.title: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts
article.author: Melissa Gray|Sania Farooqui

content: The latest deaths bring to six the number of cheetahs that have died since being reintroduced into India.

article.title: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts
article.author: Melissa Gray|Sania Farooqui

content: Siyaya gave birth to the cubs more than 70 years after cheetahs were declared extinct in India. It took a multi-step journey to get her and seven other cats from Namibia, on Africa’s southwestern coast, to central India.

article.title: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts
article.author: Melissa Gray|Sania Farooqui

content: Another 12 cheetahs arrived from South Africa in February.

article.title: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts
article.author: Melissa Gray|Sania Farooqui

content: But since then, three adult cheetahs have died. One South African cheetah died during an attempt at courtship and mating, a Namibian cheetah died of kidney disease, and a South African cheetah died due to cardiac failure.

article.title: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts
article.author: Melissa Gray|Sania Farooqui

content: Cub mortality is high in both the wild and captivity, according to the Smithsonian’s National Zoo. On average, 30% of all cubs born in human care die within one month of birth, and in Tanzania’s Serengeti National Park, about 90% die before reaching three months of age, the zoo says.

article.title: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts
article.author: Melissa Gray|Sania Farooqui

content: Cheetahs were declared extinct in India in 1952 and are the only large carnivore in the country to have suffered that fate.

article.title: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts
article.author: Melissa Gray|Sania Farooqui

content: Today, the spotted felines are most prevalent in Kenya and Tanzania in east Africa, and Namibia and Botswana in southern Africa, according to the National Zoo. But historically, the endangered cats had a much larger range, roaming throughout the Middle East and central India as well as most of sub-Saharan Africa.

article.title: Death of 3 cheetah cubs in India deals blow to reintroduction efforts
article.author: Melissa Gray|Sania Farooqui

content: Habitat loss, poaching, and conflict with humans have greatly reduced their populations. Cheetahs are now found in only 9% of their historic range, with fewer than 7,100 adult and adolescent cheetahs in the wild, according to the Cheetah Conservation Fund.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: Since about the birth of boomers, comparing the strengths and weaknesses of generations has been a perilous exercise almost guaranteed to cause offense.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: So when Australia’s Federal Police (AFP) Commissioner offered an “interesting” aside on generational differences while addressing senators in Parliament House on Thursday, there was little chance it would pass unnoticed.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: Referring to the “Pearls in Policing Conference” held in Sydney this week, where he sat next to police officers from Toronto and the United States, Commissioner Reece Kershaw said: “We learned that Gen Z, the younger generation, need three times a week praise from their supervisors, the next generation only need three times a year, and my generation only need once a year.”

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: The comment prompted raised eyebrows in the Australian parliamentary room, and no end of commentary on social media discussing the relative neediness of the nation’s youngest workers.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: The matter may have petered out, but the AFP sought to clarify the issue on Friday with a two-line statement: “Reports that AFP Commissioner believes different generations require different level of praise are incorrect. The Commissioner was referring to information recently presented to a policing forum.”

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: That information came from Michael McQueen, a social researcher and author of several books, including “How to Prepare Now for What’s Next,” who presented at the conference.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: McQueen told CNN the statistics are based on research conducted by global analytics firm Gallup and multinational software company Workhuman, who surveyed more than 10,000 adults across the US in February this year.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: According to the Gallup website, the survey found that “nearly four in 10 employees in the youngest generation of workers would prefer to be recognized by their people manager at least a few times a week.”

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: “It is not about being ‘needy’ or wanting participation trophies. Recognition provides the ingredients for employees to grow,” the website said.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: Other research shows that assessing workers’ needs based on their generation is misguided.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: A paper published in 2021 said research doesn’t support the existence of generational differences, meaning there was nothing to ‘manage’. “Much of what lay people observe as ‘generational’ at work is likely more accurately attributed to either age or career stage effects masquerading as generational differences,” the report said.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: In 2020, a study by the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine found that “categorizing workers with generational labels like ‘baby boomer’ or ‘millennial; to define their needs and behaviors is not supported by research, and cannot adequately inform workforce management decisions.”

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: “Instead of relying on generational stereotypes, employers and managers should focus on individuals’ work needs,” the research found.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: McQueen, who is a millennial, agrees that an individual approach is best, but says there’s “value in understanding broad patterns of human behavior and experience.”

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: He says the differing levels of desire for praise originate at home.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: “Over the last few decades, there’s been a lot of really good research looking at how trends in parenting and education to an extent, but especially parenting, how that has changed the way generations are growing up and how much feedback they’re looking for,” said McQueen.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: “The challenge with that is, it’s based on this flawed premise that you can give another human being self-esteem, which you sort of can’t,” he said.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: He said he’s more “intentional” about giving praise to younger staff, and he encourages businesses – and police forces – to do the same.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: During his appearance on Thursday, Kershaw also offered up what he’d learned about emojis.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: “I saw some emojis that Gen Z use that are actually offensive. But my generation is sending these emojis, so the world’s changing, I guess, is what I’m saying,” he said.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: When asked by a puzzled participant which emojis his generation was sending, Kershaw explained: “Like a happy face. That can actually mean the opposite in Gen Z land. Happy to give you a briefing on that,” he said to laughter.

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: For older readers wondering what a smiley face really means, it can be interpreted as “extreme passive aggression.”

article.title: Which generation needs more praise? Australian police commissioner clarifies Gen Z comment
article.author: Hilary Whiteman

content: “I think the safest one is just the super clear, obvious, big grin with teeth,” said McQueen. “At least it’s a proper smile.”
